metadata.synopsis: Minthara at party organized by Withers. This is the very last time we see Minthara in the game. She's in a reflective mood, and is warmer to many of the companions than previously. This is because of the bond she feels with them, having gone through a great crisis together, but also because she is now an exile and knows she needs to keep what few friends and allies she has close to her if she is to have any chance of surviving.She still has a sharp tongue, and won't take kindly to anyone acting superior to her - and she's still plotting to make herself more powerful, and willing to step on anyone who gets in the way. But she is very aware that her survival will be difficult in this new world, and she's intelligent enough not to antagonise the people who have most reason to trust her.Variants:In BG w/ PlayerIn Menzoberranzan w/ PlayerIn Avernus with KarlachIn BG or Menzoberranzan alone.

14.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
14.text: So here we are. A gathering of allies at a cold campsite, with no servants to attend us, and few luxuries to enjoy.

353.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
353.text: We could have been conquerors... we could have ruled these Realms as gods.

407.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
407.text: Do you ever regret that we did not take control of the Netherbrain?

61.speaker: Player
61.text: I did not escape Bhaal's influence to become a monster of my own free will.

489.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
489.text: Do you think of all rulers as monsters? Conquest need not end in blood and ashes. You could have built a greater world than this.

5.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
5.text: I shall not dwell on the past though. The future is unwritten, and rich with possibilities.

241.speaker: Player
241.text: You of all people should be glad the Absolute is no more. It nearly destroyed you.

597.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
597.text: True. But what better revenge could there be than enslaving the abomination that was the author of my torment.

456.speaker: Player
456.text: No. The very idea sickens me.

551.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
551.text: Hmph. If your mind is still so rigid after all it has suffered, there is little point in trying to change it.

116.speaker: Player
116.text: Of course. We gave up so much.

202.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
202.text: Regrets are of little value unless they are fuel for future victories.

572.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
572.text: Few mortals have stood against gods and monsters as we have and lived to tell the tale.

7.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
7.text: We can write our own stories now, and leave our mark on these Realms.

105.speaker: Player
105.text: And what mark have you been making, Minthara?

307.speaker: Player
307.text: Occasionally. Though I fear we would not have survived the attempt.

170.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
170.text: You may be right, but I cannot help but wish we had tried. That is in the past though.

158.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
158.text: Tell me - how goes your war against the tyrant queen?

101.speaker: Player
101.text: We seek new allies for our cause - the githzerai. Together, we will be an unstoppable force.
101.context: NodeContext: like a mentor, listening to a student

469.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
469.text: That is wise. None of us would have survived the battle against the Absolute if we had not stood together.
469.context: NodeContext: like a mentor, listening to a student

86.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
86.text: Once the fight is won, of course, you must dispose of those allies who threaten the new order.
86.context: NodeContext: like a mentor, advising a student

231.speaker: Player
231.text: You are here among allies - which among them would you dispose of?
231.context: NodeContext: intended to be reassuring, but quite sinister

465.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
465.text: Never you, Lae'zel. That is all you need to know.
465.context: NodeContext: intended to be reassuring, but quite sinister

401.speaker: Player
401.text: What have you been doing since we last met?

181.speaker: Player
181.text: I will not hesitate when the time comes.

546.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
546.text: That is why your victory is assured, and why it will usher in a new age for your people.

395.speaker: Player
395.text: A foolish notion. Slaughtering valuable associates would foment distrust.
395.context: NodeContext: like a mentor, advising a student

553.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
553.text: I did not think you an idealist, child. You can be sure that some of those who stand with you already have their hearts set on Vlaakith's vacant throne.
553.context: NodeContext: like a mentor, advising a student

323.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
323.text: They will not hesitate to claim it, and your strength is already a threat to them.
323.context: NodeContext: like a mentor, advising a student

195.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
195.text: You will learn this, or you will die.
195.context: NodeContext: like a mentor, advising a student

294.speaker: Player
294.text: I've slaughtered myriad Vlaakith loyalists. I have full confidence in our victory.
294.context: NodeContext: like a mentor, advising a student

66.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
66.text: As do I. Some would think it impossible to challenge the githyanki lich-queen, but I know you are equal to it.
66.context: NodeContext: like a mentor, advising a student

51.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
51.text: We have already done impossible things. You have done impossible things, Lae'zel of Crèche K'liir.

534.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
534.text: Nothing is beyond you, and if Vlaakith has any sense at all, she will dread your coming.

242.speaker: Player
242.text: Your confidence fills me with courage.

100.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
100.text: It is earned. The young warrior I first met was desperate for the approval and favour of her queen.

397.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
397.text: The woman who stands before me now will strike down that same queen, and win the favour of her entire people.

258.speaker: Player
258.text: Who dreads you now, Minthara? Where do you make war?

545.speaker: Player
545.text: I hope so, but I fear it is not the case.

80.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
80.text: If you were not afraid you would be delusional. Harness that fear. It can make you strong.

348.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
348.text: You may not realise it yet, but when you were a young warrior desperate for the approval and favour of Vlaakith, you knew nothing but fear.

128.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
128.text: Fear of rejection, fear of failure, fear of not living up to the impossible expectations of a mad queen.

48.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
48.text: That fear was imposed on you. The fears that you have now are yours.

198.speaker: Player
198.text: We have shown little progress. I wonder if I've pursued an impossible task.

574.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
574.text: When bards sing of our victory against the Netherbrain, those who hear it will think the story is an exaggeration, or a work of the imagination.

19.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
19.text: Is this world truly your home now, or do you still dream of a life among your own people?

520.speaker: Player
520.text: My people are the ones I chose. They are here, on Faerûn.

560.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
560.text: Only the fortunate and the bold are able to live the life they choose. I am happy for you.

514.speaker: Player
514.text: And you, Minthara? Can I be happy for you?

175.speaker: Player
175.text: Without my friends, I could not have made choices for myself.

340.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
340.text: You earned their trust, their affection, and their loyalty. That is your strength, child.

186.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
186.text: You do not need to thank me for speaking the truth.

321.speaker: Player
321.text: I have settled here well enough, though I miss being among githyanki.

539.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
539.text: Then we are more alike than I realised. Even though you chose this life, you will always be an exile while your heart belongs in another home.

11.speaker: Player
11.text: I am hunted by my own people. I don't have the luxury of returning to my kin. And you?

230.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
230.text: I have already returned... though there is little luxury there for me anymore, only war and madness.

25.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
25.text: One day, I may return to Menzoberranzan, as a conqueror or as a sacrifice. But my fight is elsewhere for now.

454.speaker: Player
454.text: You misunderstand. I will find happiness here - I just need time to adjust.

458.speaker: Player
458.text: I regret staying, some days. This world is so small... and I already feel my body growing older.

156.speaker: Player
156.text: I could ask you the same. Why not return to your home?

619.speaker: Player
619.text: There are people I've grown to care about. Some, right here in this camp.

629.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
629.text: Then this is your home, whatever regrets you might have.

219.speaker: Player
219.text: Do you have regrets? How have you been living since we last saw one another?

212.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
212.text: A word of advice? If there are those who would be hurt by your departure, do not slip away without saying goodbye.

221.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
221.text: They may be willing to follow and leave their world for you.

414.speaker: Player
414.text: What have you been doing since we last saw each other?

594.speaker: Player
594.text: Spawn? I'm the Vampire Ascendant, and you will address me as such.

180.speaker: Player
180.text: I was enjoying the flavours of the Upper City. Those who dine well make for excellent dinners.

106.speaker: Player
106.text: I was in the Lower City. Where else could I find such a worldy and diverse buffet?

559.speaker: Player
559.text: I've been savouring slum-dwellers in the Outer City. The tougher the life, the stronger the blood.

91.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
91.text: Which sewer did you crawl out of to join us here today, spawn?
91.context: NodeContext: the "uncomfortable circumstances" she refers to are the pleasant party they're attending. The next line is "In truth, I have never enjoyed parties..."

379.speaker: Player
379.text: A rather fetching one actually. It's called the Underdark - you might know it.

45.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
45.text: Hmph. I am surprised you have survived there so long. Your face shines like a sickly beacon even in this light.

416.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
416.text: Oh, but I wish I could see it. You must spend your nights cursing your cowardice, and wondering what might have been.

531.speaker: Player
531.text: You couldn't be more wrong - I'm happy with the choices I made.

604.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
604.text: Cazador really did teach you to ignore the stars in favour of your gutter.

540.speaker: Player
540.text: And you must spend your nights waiting for one of your many enemies to cut your throat.

485.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
485.text: Yes - my life is rich. A night without an assassin is a dull night indeed.

552.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
552.text: Dawn will be breaking soon. I need to guard my complexion... you need to guard your life.

206.speaker: Player
206.text: What do you do with yourself these days?

377.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
377.text: Ha - of course not. I am teasing you.

607.speaker: Player
607.text: If that's a joke, it's in very poor taste.

475.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
475.text: Then it would fit well with that ludicrous hairstyle you're so fond of.

328.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
328.text: Ha. Do not do anything that you would regret - I am, how do you say, pulling your limb.

581.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
581.text: If I ever meet that ancient fop, Cazador, I will reduce him to dust.

568.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
568.text: If I do you that service, I will expect something in return.

464.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
464.text: The city, of course. The site of our triumph.

255.speaker: Player
255.text: I have a little boudoir just below a new drow restaurant in the Lower City. It's very fungal - you'd like it.

308.speaker: Player
308.text: I'd rather live in a sewer alone than in a palace with you.

287.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
287.text: I will have a palace soon enough, and when I do, I shall make you my jester.

109.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
109.text: Fresh from the farm, Jenevelle? It is good to see you.
109.context: NodeContext: the "uncomfortable circumstances" she refers to are the pleasant party they're attending. The next line is "In truth, I have never enjoyed parties..."

288.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
288.text: Shar inflicted such misery on you. Most would find it unbearable, but you have shown resilience.

260.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
260.text: Any who survive the torments of the gods deserve peace. Most never find it.

35.speaker: Player
35.text: Peace was never my goal, but I'm content for now.

505.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
505.text: Then your adventuring days are not behind you. That is good. You are young yet, and these Realms are wide and full of wonder.

265.speaker: Player
265.text: Of a sort. But I miss the open skies and open roads.

471.speaker: Player
471.text: Yes. If I can spend the rest of my days without unleashing another Guiding Bolt I'll be happy.

247.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
247.text: Perhaps. But do not be surprised if you hear the howl of the wolves one night, or see a sign flashing across the stars, and leave your hearth behind.

150.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
150.text: I do not think your adventuring days are behind you.

515.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
515.text: Tranquility will always be waiting, at the end of your journey. Wherever it takes you.

511.speaker: Player
511.text: What about you, Minthara? Where has your journey taken you?

132.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
132.text: Young Ravengard. My sources tell me you have returned to your former career - terrorising the Frontiers.
132.context: NodeContext: the "uncomfortable circumstances" she refers to are the pleasant party they're attending. The next line is "In truth, I have never enjoyed parties..."

322.speaker: Player
322.text: I do more good than harm, even with Mizora whispering in my ear.

419.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
419.text: Can you ever be sure though? How many of the monsters you kill are simply defending their way of life from those your blade protects?

398.speaker: Player
398.text: It's better for me to be far from the city, given Mizora's influence on me.

79.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
79.text: I doubt those you turn your blade against would agree.

271.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
271.text: The devil is a subtle creature. She will do as she always has - select victims that resemble monsters, and use your talents to dispose of them.

124.speaker: Player
124.text: I can live with the occasional mistake.

174.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
174.text: Then you are wiser than I thought.

536.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
536.text: Well met, young Ravengard. May your blade strike true more often than not.

561.speaker: Player
561.text: What have you been doing since we last met?

441.speaker: Player
441.text: I'm not a fool. I can see through Mizora's lies.

63.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
63.text: Impressive. She has taught you to deceive yourself so adeptly that perhaps she does not need to direct you at all.

270.speaker: Player
270.text: I don't have a choice in the matter.

87.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
87.text: You could choose to lay down your blade, to lay down your life, to give up your soul. That you do not tells me which life matters most to you.

273.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
273.text: Well met, young Ravengard. I do not think our paths shall cross again.

211.speaker: Player
211.text: I didn't expect you of all people to be judgemental.

362.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
362.text: I did not expect you of all people to be a devil's lapdog for the rest of your days.

176.speaker: Player
176.text: Your sources are wrong. I'm free of Mizora - I'm a true hero now.

524.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
524.text: I am sure that being slain by a heroic blade is of great comfort to your victims.

147.speaker: Player
147.text: They are not victims, they are monsters.

146.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
146.text: I have been both victim and monster. Whichever you saw me as, if your turned your blade on me, there are still those who would grieve my passing.

508.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
508.text: And I would bleed like any other.

325.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
325.text: I was taught that any man who spoke out of line, or above his lowly station, should be punished. I called that justice.

217.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
217.text: I do not think there is such a thing as justice anymore, and I do not find my comfort at either end of a blade.

374.speaker: Player
374.text: I'm a protector, not a killer.

556.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
556.text: In this world, the two roles go hand in hand more often than not.

313.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
313.text: Call yourself a slayer of monsters and be proud, for that is what you are.

406.speaker: Player
406.text: Only evil needs fear my blade.

151.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
151.text: Tenday after tenday without a word. No letter, no sending stone, no communication at all.
151.context: NodeContext: the "uncomfortable circumstances" she refers to are the pleasant party they're attending. The next line is "In truth, I have never enjoyed parties..."

509.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
509.text: Even the head of an imp would have been enough - anything to show you were still alive.
509.context: NodeContext: the "uncomfortable circumstances" she refers to are the pleasant party they're attending. The next line is "In truth, I have never enjoyed parties..."

305.speaker: Player
305.text: I'm sorry, it's no easy thing to get a message out of Avernus.
305.context: NodeContext: the "uncomfortable circumstances" she refers to are the pleasant party they're attending. The next line is "In truth, I have never enjoyed parties..."

555.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
555.text: Nothing worth doing is 'easy'. If anyone has proven that, we have.

88.speaker: Player
88.text: Of course I was still alive - where's your faith in me?
88.context: NodeContext: the "uncomfortable circumstances" she refers to are the pleasant party they're attending. The next line is "In truth, I have never enjoyed parties..."

333.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
333.text: Perhaps you took it to Avernus when you left. It certainly felt like it.

448.speaker: Player
448.text: We were fighting for Karlach's life.
448.context: NodeContext: the "uncomfortable circumstances" she refers to are the pleasant party they're attending. The next line is "In truth, I have never enjoyed parties..."

40.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
40.text: Of course you were. And sacrificing our life together in the process.
40.context: NodeContext: the "uncomfortable circumstances" she refers to are the pleasant party they're attending. The next line is "In truth, I have never enjoyed parties..."

373.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
373.text: But I am not unreasonable. I am willing to forgive this dalliance, on one condition.
373.context: NodeContext: the "uncomfortable circumstances" she refers to are the pleasant party they're attending. The next line is "In truth, I have never enjoyed parties..."

292.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
292.text: Promise that once you are done in the Hells, you will return to my side. And help me take Baldur's Gate.
292.context: NodeContext: the "uncomfortable circumstances" she refers to are the pleasant party they're attending. The next line is "In truth, I have never enjoyed parties..."

46.speaker: Player
46.context: NodeContext: the "uncomfortable circumstances" she refers to are the pleasant party they're attending. The next line is "In truth, I have never enjoyed parties..."

17.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
17.text: Of course it is - my feelings demand a high price. This should not come as a surprise.

191.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
191.text: You could have dominated the Netherbrain and given me all of Faerûn. This is a bargain by comparison.

385.speaker: Player
385.text: Agreed. We'll start on our plans once I'm back.
385.context: NodeContext: the "uncomfortable circumstances" she refers to are the pleasant party they're attending. The next line is "In truth, I have never enjoyed parties..."

510.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
510.text: Truly? I admit, I never thought you were quite this romantic, my love.
510.context: NodeContext: the "uncomfortable circumstances" she refers to are the pleasant party they're attending. The next line is "In truth, I have never enjoyed parties..."

303.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
303.text: A pity we are rekindling this relationship in such... uncomfortable circumstances.
303.context: NodeContext: the "uncomfortable circumstances" she refers to are the pleasant party they're attending. The next line is "In truth, I have never enjoyed parties..."

143.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
143.text: A pity. But if you will not help me, I am more than happy to help myself.

10.speaker: Player
10.text: I sent dozens of messages! Didn't you get them?

426.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
426.text: They were intercepted? A worrying thought, that some imp or devil may be perusing your messages to me.

518.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
518.text: They were intercepted? A worrying thought, that some imp or devil may be perusing your messages to me.

304.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
304.text: Not that this takes away from your original sin. You still left me here, after all.

403.text: I almost admire your boldness, trying to lie to me. As if you forget to whom you speak.

523.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
523.text: I almost admire your boldness, trying to lie to me. As if you forget to whom you speak.

161.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
161.text: I am glad to see you, Karlach. Your heart can survive the Hells, but I feared your spirit would not.
161.context: CinematicNodeContext: Minthara kisses the player MINDFLAYER

71.speaker: Player
71.text: I'm still standing. I even smile, from time to time.

252.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
252.text: I have seen you without a smile. It is a poor sight indeed.

178.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
178.text: I am still establishing a foothold in Baldur's Gate, but soon I will have strength enough to aid you.

484.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
484.text: When that is the case, I will gladly come to Avernus to fight by your side once again.

312.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
312.text: I have a war of my own to fight, against my mother and her people, and there is every chance I will not survive it.

122.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
122.text: But if I do, I will gladly bring my strength to Avernus to fight by your side again.

276.speaker: Player
276.text: Thanks. I need all the help I can get.

371.speaker: Player
371.text: I don't understand why you're so kind to me.

453.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
453.text: If the tadpoles still allowed us to share ourselves, I could show you.

342.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
342.text: Even then, you may not understand. As it is, you never will, because there are no words in my language or yours to explain such mysteries of the heart.

320.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
320.text: Helping an ally is its own reward. But I can think of few greater challenges than battling across the Hells.

199.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
199.text: Besides, what else would you have me do? Lay down my weapons and spend my last centuries growing plump? I think not.

37.speaker: Player
37.text: So! What've you been up to, Minthara?

402.speaker: Player
402.text: Spirit's still rattling around in there somewhere. Not sure it'll last, though - if I will.

278.speaker: Player
278.text: Don't worry about me. Takes more than eternal war to knock me on my ass.

625.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
625.text: I have no doubt, but you need not fight alone.

188.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
188.text: Young Ravengard. An honour as always.
188.context: CinematicNodeContext: Minthara kisses the player MINDFLAYER

567.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
567.text: How is the view from the Upper City?

522.speaker: Player
522.text: It would be a lot more pleasant if you weren't lurking in the shadows, causing trouble.

549.speaker: Player
549.text: Better by the day. The city is recovering.

591.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
591.text: How could it not with you to guide the reconstruction?

104.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
104.text: It is not only dukes and partriars who are doing their part though. I am helping too, in my own way.

110.speaker: Player
110.text: I find that hard to believe. You're a troublemaker.

138.speaker: Player
138.text: What exactly are you doing to help?

117.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
117.text: Given your position, there are certain things that must go unsaid, but let us just say I do what you cannot to keep the city strong.

136.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
136.text: By toxin, blade or word, I weed out the weak and the untrustworthy. You may not like my methods, but our goals align.

272.speaker: Player
272.text: I'm more interested in how you see things from your spot in the Lower City.

237.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
237.text: I do not have a 'spot', I have a network. Our eyes see a city that needs help from the top and the bottom.

493.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
493.text: We can help, but we need your people to stay out of our way.

214.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
214.text: It is good to see you, Jenevelle. How do your parents fare?
214.context: CinematicNodeContext: Minthara kisses the player MINDFLAYER

16.speaker: Player
16.text: They are making up for lost time, living the best life they can.

343.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
343.text: To endure the agonies Shar inflicted on them for so long shows resilience. They deserve peace.

275.speaker: Player
275.text: What they went through will haunt them forever - but they're strong.

47.speaker: Player
47.text: I worry about them. How can they ever adjust to a normal life?

490.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
490.text: What is 'normal'? You and I were born to do extraordinary things - we have challenged the gods and live to tell of it.

107.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
107.text: We undid the Grand Design, and saved Baldur's Gate from annihilation.

266.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
266.text: We - and they - need not adjust. We need only endure until we can claim the position we deserve.

253.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
253.text: We will spend the rest of our lives together. Go, be with the others.
253.context: CinematicNodeContext: Minthara kisses the player MINDFLAYER

38.speaker: Player
38.text: How about a quick kiss first?
38.context: CinematicNodeContext: Minthara kisses the player MINDFLAYER

602.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
602.text: Of course. On this occasion, you need not even earn it, my sweet.
602.context: CinematicNodeContext: Minthara kisses the player MINDFLAYER

30.context: CinematicNodeContext: Minthara kisses the player MINDFLAYER

263.context: CinematicNodeContext: Minthara kisses the player TALL

121.context: CinematicNodeContext: Minthara kisses the player TALL

309.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
309.context: CinematicNodeContext: with a nod of acknowledgmentNodeContext: A greeting to Gale, who she still only acknowledges as 'wizard' despite all they've been through as a team

472.speaker: Player
472.context: NodeContext: contemptuous - Gale just referred to her as 'drow'.

341.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
341.context: NodeContext: contemptuous - Gale just referred to her as 'drow'.

293.speaker: Player
293.text: I refuse to believe you still don't know my name after all we went through together.
293.context: NodeContext: listing off things she knows about Gale to prove that she pays attention to him - amused

364.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
364.text: Your tressym is called Tara and she dislikes your beard. She is wrong - it is a fine beard. Dashing, even.
364.context: NodeContext: listing off things she knows about Gale to prove that she pays attention to him - amused

569.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
569.text: You enjoy travel and adventure, but miss Waterdeep whenever you are away. This is because your mind is restless, and can only find peace in familiar places.
569.context: NodeContext: listing off things she knows about Gale to prove that she pays attention to him - amused, but genuinely insightful

587.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
587.text: Your ambition is not cruel, but you fear that if you indulge it, you will lose yourself in the mysteries of the Weave and unravel the world.
587.context: NodeContext: listing off things she knows about Gale to prove that she pays attention to him - amused, but genuinely insightful

548.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
548.text: You are afraid of so many things, and it is that fear that keeps you true to yourself.
548.context: NodeContext: listing off things she knows about Gale to prove that she pays attention to him - amused, but genuinely insightful

537.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
537.text: I know a great deal about you, Gale Dekarios. And that is precisely why I know how enjoyable it is to tease and befuddle you.
537.context: NodeContext: listing off things she knows about Gale to prove that she pays attention to him - amused, but genuinely insightful

584.speaker: Player
584.text: You're still as rude as ever.

404.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
404.text: And you're still the same charming blend of pompous and naive. It is good that there are some constants in these maddening Realms.

532.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
532.text: Do not tell the others, or I'll clip your pussycat's wings.
532.context: CinematicNodeContext: They share a quick hug

451.text: Do not tell the others, or I'll clip your pussycat's wings.
451.context: CinematicNodeContext: They share a quick hug

528.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
528.text: Do not tell the others, or I'll clip your pussycat's wings.
528.context: NodeContext: A friendly and not-serious warning about not telling the others about a moment of friendliness

359.speaker: Player
359.text: Do that and I'll cast an infestation on you, and acquaint you with a whole new set of parasites.

250.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
250.text: You are many things Gale: the Wizard of Waterdeep, a man who has touched divinity, and the owner of a rather dashing beard.

36.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
36.text: You are many things Gale: the Wizard of Waterdeep, a man who has touched divinity, and the owner of a rather dashing beard.

39.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
39.text: But a keeper of secrets you are not.

296.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
296.text: Do not tell the others, or I'll set fire to your library.
296.context: NodeContext: A friendly and not-serious warning about not telling the others about a moment of friendliness

513.speaker: Player
513.text: Drop the act, Minthara. I know you want to give me a hug.

283.speaker: Player
283.text: I've become so much more than 'human'.

334.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
334.text: Is that the smell of brimstone I detect, young Ravengard?
334.context: NodeContext: amused, mocking Wyll lightly because he is still pacted to a devil

615.speaker: Player
615.text: Address me by my title, Minthara. Grand Duke Ravengard.
615.context: NodeContext: mocking - Mizora is the devil Wyll is pacted to

192.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
192.text: Of course. And to ensure I do not break protocol... should I refer to the lady Mizora as your Grand Duchess?
192.context: NodeContext: mocking - Mizora is the devil Wyll is pacted to

386.speaker: Player
386.text: Is my pact amusing to you?

487.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
487.text: Of course. The city's prodigal son, returned as a saviour, and yoked to a devil - it is such a perfect satire, who could help but laugh?

483.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
483.text: Oh, but I have upset you.

254.speaker: Player
254.text: She acts as such. I'll never be rid of her.

599.speaker: Player
599.text: Keep your nose out of my business.

396.speaker: Player
396.text: It's a new scented water. Very fashionable among the aristocracy.

519.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
519.text: Baldur's Gate doesn't have an aristocracy. Your Council of Four is a rogues gallery of merchants, politicians and adventurers.

225.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
225.text: And then of course there's your lady Mizora, to make a Council of Five.
225.context: NodeContext: mocking - Mizora is the devil Wyll is pacted to, to his shame

431.speaker: Player
431.text: Mizora's scent is as hard to wash off as her influence.
431.context: NodeContext: teasing on the first phrase - she has some sympathy, but she's enjoying his plight

586.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
586.text: Poor Wyll. What does the devil ask of you?
586.context: NodeContext: teasing on the first phrase - she has some sympathy, but she's enjoying his plight

295.speaker: Player
295.text: She helps the city to prosper, if you can believe it.
295.context: NodeContext: speaking the truth - she does want Baldur's Gate to prosper - because she wants to profit from it

85.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
85.context: NodeContext: speaking the truth - she does want Baldur's Gate to prosper - because she wants to profit from it

201.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
201.text: Just as I have the best interests of Baldur's Gate at heart, so does Mizora.
201.context: NodeContext: speaking the truth - she does want Baldur's Gate to prosper - because she wants to profit from it

235.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
235.text: Neither of us can profit from a city in decline. We will see it flourish, and we will share in its prosperity.
235.context: NodeContext: speaking the truth - she does want Baldur's Gate to prosper - because she wants to profit from it

173.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
173.text: Baldur's Gate is her home now, thanks to you, and she cannot profit from a city in decline. She will see it flourish, and she will share in its prosperity.

59.speaker: Player
59.context: NodeContext: teasing Wyll, trying to make him paranoid

118.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
118.text: That is troubling. Just as great tapestries begin with a single stitch, the most treacherous plots begin with a few whispered words.
118.context: NodeContext: teasing Wyll, trying to make him paranoid

317.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
317.text: I fear you are engaged in a grand game of Lanceboard, young Wyll, and you are already four moves behind.
317.context: NodeContext: teasing Wyll, trying to make him paranoid - 'Lanceboard' is the local equivalent of chess

223.speaker: Player
223.text: It doesn't help that you're skulking around the city causing trouble.
223.context: NodeContext: teasing - she's acting like a Mafia boss who knows she's above the law

29.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
29.text: If I were causing trouble, surely your Flaming Fist would have paid me a visit in these last six months?
29.context: NodeContext: teasing - she's acting like a Mafia boss who knows she's above the law

89.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
89.text: In fact, when I pass them in the street, they wish me 'good day' and 'good fortune'.
89.context: NodeContext: teasing - she's acting like a Mafia boss who knows she's above the law

473.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
473.text: Do not forget, young Ravengard, that I too am one of the saviours of Baldur's Gate. I stood with you when the city was on its knees.
473.context: NodeContext: teasing - she's acting like a Mafia boss who knows she's above the law

142.speaker: Player
142.text: I can't argue with that. Let there be peace between us.
142.context: NodeContext: teasing - no glass to raise, it's a nod of mocking respect rather than a toast

408.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
408.text: To peace and prosperity. You will make an excellent Grand Duke, Wyll Ravengard.
408.context: NodeContext: teasing - no glass to raise, it's a nod of mocking respect rather than a toast

425.speaker: Player
425.text: You'd have the city on its knees again if you could.

166.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
166.text: If the city should fall, I will be here to raise it again. I am many things, but I am not a fool.

445.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
445.text: While Baldur's Gate is my home, I would see it stronger than its neighbours, and I will do everything in my power to make it so.

588.speaker: Player
588.text: True. And yet I still don't trust you.
588.context: NodeContext: mocking - she doesn't care about his opinion so she's not wounded at all

285.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
285.context: NodeContext: mocking - she doesn't care about his opinion so she's not wounded at all

589.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
589.text: We do not need to trust one another. Just stay out of my way.

413.speaker: Player
413.text: Step out of line and I'll have no choice but to get in your way.

330.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
330.text: If that day ever comes, I look forward to seeing how much the wine and good living has dulled your blade.

207.speaker: Player
207.text: I'll be keeping an eye on you.

239.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
239.text: Make sure it is the good one.

372.speaker: Player
372.text: I'm sure your life isn't particularly comfortable, given your exile from the Underdark.

27.speaker: Player
27.text: It's none of your damn business.

218.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
218.text: As you wish. I have business of my own to attend to, after all.

554.speaker: Player
554.text: What business would that be? Troublemaking, no doubt.

337.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
337.text: Yes, my love? Are you done talking to your friends? Can we leave?

339.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
339.text: Yes, my love? Are you done talking to your friends? Can we leave?

579.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
579.text: They may respect me or fear me, but I do not think they like me.

140.speaker: Player
140.text: Of course they do. You're the life of the party.

185.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
185.text: What makes me so? My quick wit? My cold heart? My cutting insights?

368.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
368.text: In truth, I have never enjoyed parties... although they do present the perfect opportunity for a poisoning.

167.speaker: Player
167.text: Please don't poison any of our friends, Minthara.

54.speaker: Player
54.text: You're the funniest person I know.

301.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
301.text: Taste my lips. They are already laced with toxins - none shall be spared tonight, not even you.

497.speaker: Player
497.text: What a wonderful way to die.

507.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
507.text: Enjoy your time with the others, because I do not plan to share you for long.

345.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
345.text: Soon we shall be together, and I will not want to let you go again.

390.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
390.text: Tomorrow we return to Avernus, and our campaign against Zariel continues.

393.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
393.text: We will need all of our strength.

248.speaker: Player
248.text: Keep some of your strength for tonight. My body is yours.

376.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
376.text: I always have strength enough for you. Do not make me wait long.

633.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
633.text: Tomorrow we return to Baldur's Gate, and our campaign to control the city's undesirables continues.

447.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
447.text: Tomorrow we return to the Underdark, and our campaign against my House continues.

171.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
171.text: Of course not. I was simply playing my part, and trying to have a little fun.

418.speaker: Player
418.text: You handle the drinks, I'll handle the food. They'll all be dead by dawn.

137.speaker: Player
137.text: I'm sure some of them like you.

436.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
436.text: Your affection is the only thing that matters.

577.speaker: Player
577.text: I don't think they like me very much either.

369.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
369.text: Then they are fools. You are the best of them, or I would not have chosen you.

411.speaker: Player
411.text: I like you. That's the most important thing.

111.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
111.text: Let us finish our socialising and be done.

153.speaker: Player
153.text: Aren't you enjoying seeing everyone again?

154.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
154.text: I have hosted gatherings of House Matrons and High Priestesses who wanted nothing more than to murder one another before the night was done.

227.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
227.text: I have negotiated the handover of hostages and smiled politely while sensing a dagger at my back.

302.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
302.text: I thought I was equal to anything. But this is all so... pleasant. And I am not even sure anyone here likes me.

183.speaker: Player
183.text: I've never seen you so anxious.

347.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
347.text: The great vampire lord. Tell me - where is the best feeding ground in Baldur's Gate?

135.speaker: Player
135.text: The Upper City. Those who dine well, make fine dinners.

187.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
187.text: Hmm. I expected too much meat and wine might cause the blood to curdle like day-old milk.

299.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
299.text: I wish you well, Lord Astarion.

159.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
159.text: Just remember, if you are ever tempted to taste my blood, you may enjoy the taste, but not the toxins.

97.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
97.text: Oh, and Astarion - the next time you throw one of your infamous masquerades, I would be delighted to attend.

381.speaker: Player
381.text: I'll be sure to send an invitation.

627.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
627.text: Excellent. It will save me the effort of sneaking in under a false name. It is tiresome to masquerade before the ball even begins.

3.speaker: Player
3.text: I prefer the company of the finer folks of the city, I'm afraid.

267.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
267.text: If you can not recognise my qualities, you can wear Cazador's title and squat in his palace for as long as you like.

44.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
44.text: You will always be a scared little spawn.

9.speaker: Player
9.text: My dear - do you mean to say the ravishing creature with the Orin mask I met just last night wasn't you?

68.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
68.text: Of course. But next time, a formal invitation if you please.

387.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
387.text: I shall see you in the city.

144.speaker: Player
144.text: The Lower City presents the most fabulous and diverse buffet.

478.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
478.text: A varied diet is indeed the key to a long life.

108.speaker: Player
108.text: Those who live hard lives have strong blood. The Outer City is without compare.

442.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
442.text: If the inhabitants taste anything like they smell, you have peculiar taste indeed.

326.speaker: Player
326.text: I like to import my food. Chult, Amn, Waterdeep, the Moonshae Isles - they all produce fine stock.

420.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
420.text: This night shall be done sooner than any of us would like. I hope we meet again.

517.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
517.text: There is more to you than I recognised at first, young Ravengard.

2.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
2.text: I thought you vainglorious, and saw your adventures on the frontiers as little more than an excuse to grow your legend.

23.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
23.text: Now you fight in the Hells, where there is little to be gained, and much to be lost.

525.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
525.text: It is courageous, or it is foolish, but it is certainly not self-serving.

350.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
350.text: Then it is courage that drives you. And love.

501.speaker: Player
501.text: Only a fool would willingly commit themselves to the Hells.

282.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
282.text: Better to be a fool with a purpose than an idle politician. Better to be a devil-slayer than a Duke.

172.speaker: Player
172.text: It takes courage to hunt in the Hells, I won't deny it.

352.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
352.text: Everyone in these Realms is afraid of something. Wolves, sunlight, beasts, fiends, death... loneliness.

189.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
189.text: But those who fear themselves travel the most difficult road to find their courage. You have done so, Wyll.

389.speaker: Player
389.text: You've got it all wrong. I am in it for the glory.

90.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
90.text: Well, then you are a greater fool than I thought. There is no glory in the Hells.

103.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
103.text: But at least you have risen to a greater challenge than slaying goblins and bugbears.

210.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
210.text: You have become a better man than you were.

558.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
558.text: I will never understand why people thank one another for making honest observations.

424.speaker: Player
424.text: What have you been doing since we last met?

259.speaker: Player
259.text: I was always a good man.

370.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
370.text: Not by my estimation, but you do not need to concern yourself with that.

249.speaker: Player
249.text: I think your idea of 'good' might be very different to mine.

8.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
8.text: You are correct, but our differences are unimportant when it comes to this matter.

280.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
280.text: We can agree that you have become a better man.

297.speaker: Player
297.text: Have you become a good woman?

256.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
256.text: Yes, Wyll. I am a paragon of virtue. I volunteer at a local orphanage, and rehabilitate wounded owlbear cubs.

433.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
433.text: All so that the children and cubs alike can be moulded to my purpose, raised in my image, and made willing to die in my name.

626.speaker: Player
626.text: Are you trying to be funny?

26.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
26.text: Let us simply agree that no matter what I am, you have become a better man.

538.speaker: Player
538.text: You really are a horrible person.

624.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
624.text: And you have no sense of humour.

598.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
598.text: Dekarios the divine graces us with his presence. I hope you do not expect me to bow or utter a prayer in your honour.
598.context: NodeContext: Greeting Gale in a situation where he has become a god. She's mock-deferential - she has a grudging admiration for Gale, but she'll be damned if she's going to show it

228.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
228.text: The only thing more insufferable than a wizard is a god.
228.context: NodeContext: playfully mocking rather than outright cruel

50.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
50.text: Better gods than you have tried.

289.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
289.text: I am glad to hear that smiting is in your divine repertoire though. I feared you would be a dull kind of god.

576.speaker: Player
576.text: To be honest, a god's work is mostly bureaucratic.
576.context: NodeContext: amused by Gale being boring even as a god

21.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
21.text: There is the wizard I remember. Finding the dreariness in divinity.
21.context: NodeContext: amused by Gale being boring even as a god

533.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
533.text: It is good to see you, Gale.
533.context: NodeContext: quiet, warm - she's been mocking Gale, but she's genuinely glad to see him

566.speaker: Player
566.text: Divinity is anything but dull. I've seen such wonders as you wouldn't believe.
566.context: NodeContext: sad but reflective, as she reflects on how difficult her life has become

236.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
236.text: You are correct, no doubt. I have seen more terrors than wonders since we last met.
236.context: NodeContext: sad but reflective, as she reflects on how difficult her life has become

127.speaker: Player
127.text: I only smite people who really deserve it.
127.context: NodeContext: playful - suggesting she is one of the ones who would smite back

477.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
477.text: Your godhood will have a much stronger chance of staying intact if you only smite those who do not smite back.
477.context: NodeContext: playful - suggesting she is one of the ones who would smite back

634.speaker: Player
634.text: I'm assuming your life has been anything but dull?

527.speaker: Player
527.text: Oh, I can think of something more insufferable than either - a haughty down-on-her-luck drow.

460.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
460.text: Then we are fortunate there is nobody fitting that description here. My fortunes have only improved since the defeat of the Netherbrain.

495.speaker: Player
495.text: I do expect you to bow, actually. Do it.

504.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
504.text: I bow to nobody, wizard, and you should not expect me to. We defeated the Absolute together. We are equals.

570.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
570.text: And it is only your ascension to godhood that makes you so. As a mortal, you were scarcely fit to look at me.

450.speaker: Player
450.text: It's good to see you too, Minthara.
450.context: NodeContext: mild annoyance because Gale is being NICE to her, and has made her feel friendly

268.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
268.context: NodeContext: mild annoyance because Gale is being NICE to her, and has made her feel friendly

246.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
246.text: Do not tell the others, or I'll burn down the first Galerian temple I see.
246.context: CinematicNodeContext: They share a quick hug

194.text: Do not tell the others, or I'll burn down the first Galerian temple I see.
194.context: CinematicNodeContext: They share a quick hug

440.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
440.text: Do not tell the others, or I'll burn down the first Galerian temple I see.
440.context:
NodeContext: A friendly and not-serious warning about not telling the others about a moment of friendliness

Galerian ryhmes with Valerian (vuh-leer-ee-uhn)

573.speaker: Player
573.text: Careful. My acolytes won't take too kindly to that. Nor will I.

113.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
113.text: There is no mark you could put upon me, or proclamation you could make against me, that would make my life more hazardous than it already is.

327.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
327.text: I have survived this much of my exile, but I have few friends left in this world. Or any other.

521.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
521.text: You are many things, Gale. The man who became a god, the Wizard of Waterdeep... but a keeper of secrets you are not.

500.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
500.text: I expect everyone will know of my affection for you by morning, but it does not matter. Tomorrow, I will be far from here.

244.speaker: Player
244.text: I always knew you had a soft heart.

196.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
196.text: I always thought you had a sharp mind - your misreading of me suggests otherwise.

446.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
446.text: Given where I tread, I would not survive if my heart were not as hard as my blades are sharp.

613.speaker: Player
613.text: You missed me, didn't you? I always knew you cared about me.

82.speaker: Player
82.text: Where have you been causing trouble since I last saw you?

486.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
486.text: Now that Karlach and I are united against Zariel's legions, Avernus burns hotter than ever.

544.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
544.text: I fear there can be no victory in the war that has chosen us, but every moment we spend together is cause for celebration.

603.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
603.text: And every foe we vanquish makes me glad to be alive, for however many days remain.

72.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
72.text: Baldur's Gate needs fresh leadership, and I am only too happy to provide. I keep to the shadows, of course, for the sake of my complexion.
72.context: NodeContext: with a smile - an honest-to-goodness Minthara joke on the last phrase

34.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
34.text: With our adventures behind me, it is good to engage with the intrigue of politics again.
34.context: NodeContext: pleased - scheming really is her happy place

15.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
15.text: Even the most cunning Baldurian conspirator would struggle to survive a tenday in Menzoberranzan.
15.context: NodeContext: pleased - scheming really is her happy place

134.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
134.text: They will learn from me, or they will bow to me.
134.context: NodeContext: a simple statement of fact

503.speaker: Player
503.text: I may no longer be your lover, but I am the god of ambition. If you desire my aid, you've only to ask.
503.context: NodeContext: Matter of fact - not just a statement about GodGale, but any god

628.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
628.text: An intriguing proposition. To harness the powers of the heavens as I once harnessed you...

488.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
488.text: I will think on it, but I make no promises.

224.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
224.text: We do not know yet what calibre of god you will prove to be.

76.speaker: Player
76.text: Quite the ambition. We could do great things together, you and I...
76.context: NodeContext: Matter of fact - not just a statement about GodGale, but any god

611.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
611.text: I would no more allow a god to shape my destiny than I would a pigeon.
611.context: NodeContext: Matter of fact - not just a statement about GodGale, but any god

152.speaker: Player
152.text: Sounds like you need no help from me.

141.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
141.text: Naturally. A fledgling god is of little use where my plans are concerned.

64.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
64.text: You may observe my works, if you lack sufficient occupations of your own. But do not interfere, unless you wish to learn how fleeting divinity can be.
64.context: NodeContext: Only a hint of a threat, not too ominous

542.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
542.text: Either way, the city's future is assured. I will make it my home, and in time, Waterdeep, Neverwinter and the rest... they will be my vassals.
542.context: NodeContext: pleased - scheming really is her happy place

612.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
612.text: I feared that returning to the Underdark as an apostate of Lolth would be an act of madness.
612.context: NodeContext: talking about the dangerous war she is waging against Lolth

284.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
284.text: Perhaps it was. If so, it is a madness that fits me well.
284.context: NodeContext: talking about the dangerous war she is waging against Lolth

562.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
562.text: Rebels swarm to my cause, and even if it takes centuries, I will reclaim my House in Menzoberranzan, and make the Spider-Queen bleed.
562.context: NodeContext: talking about the dangerous war she is waging against Lolth

324.speaker: Player
324.text: Is that any way to greet your lover?
324.context: NodeContext: playfully mocking rather than outright cruel

6.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
6.text: Were I to take a lover from the Faerûnian pantheon, I assure you it would not be the runt of the litter.
6.context: NodeContext: playfully mocking rather than outright cruel

601.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
601.text: I am surprised you dare face me, after departing as you did.

354.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
354.text: Perhaps you think yourself safe in this projected form, but I assure you, if I wanted you dead, you would be.

162.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
162.text: So. What do you have to say for yourself?

596.speaker: Player
596.text: I could not leave my people at Vlaakith's mercy.

42.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
42.text: Of course you could leave them! You owe your people nothing.

264.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
264.text: No, you were presented with a choice of paths. And you chose poorly.

130.speaker: Player
130.text: I'm sorry, I wish I'd made a different choice.

22.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
22.text: A pity, you could have at least had the conviction of your choice. Now you simply look weak.

380.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
380.text: But if your senses ever grace you with their presence again and you wish to return to my side... I may consider your plea.

608.speaker: Player
608.text: What have you been doing since I left?

541.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
541.text: Do not mistake this benevolence for indulgence. My patience is gossamer thin.

139.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
139.text: You have not asked about my activities since your departure, but you should know I have been thriving.

361.speaker: Player
361.text: I stand by my decision. It was the right thing to do.

56.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
56.text: I see... Good. I may not agree with your choice, but at least you have conviction in it.

102.speaker: Player
102.text: I wasn't leaving Lae'zel to face Vlaakith's forces alone.

585.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
585.text: Lae'zel has an army - she is hardly alone. And she certainly does not need you to protect her.

306.speaker: Player
306.text: You are more than welcome to join our fight.

131.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
131.text: I think not. I have my own goals and fighting someone else's war does nothing to advance them.

277.speaker: Player
277.text: Would you have passed up an opportunity like that?

286.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
286.text: I would have. Every opportunity comes with a cost, but you were more than happy to pay this one.

630.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
630.text: Greetings. Does your cloister thrive, Shadowheart?

129.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
129.text: If you ever need advice, do let me know. I have experience leading treacherous cults.

336.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
336.text: The key is to ensure your followers rely on you, but cannot rely on one another. That way, they cannot unite against you.

220.speaker: Player
220.text: You want my people divided so that we're not a threat to your ambitions.

449.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
449.text: I need do nothing to ensure you are no threat to my ambitions.

55.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
55.text: I tire of feuding with the gods.

481.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
481.text: You and Lady Shar may claim the souls of Baldur's Gate. I will focus my attention on material things.

62.speaker: Player
62.text: What have you been up to since we last met?

77.speaker: Player
77.text: Perhaps you can give me more than advice - help me to run the Cloister.

160.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
160.text: I like you, child, but I will not give my allegiance to a god.

467.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
467.text: But I promise not to interfere with your activities.

583.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
583.text: You need not thank me for advice.

474.speaker: Player
474.text: I would rather promote unity than suspicion.

394.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
394.text: Then you have been chosen by the wrong goddess. Poor child.

70.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
70.text: I offer it freely. Do with it as you wish.

457.speaker: Player
457.text: It will take a while for me to gain full control.

434.speaker: Player
434.text: I hope so, but I fear I am failing Lady Shar.
